question:
(a) (i) Draw a well labelled diagram to show the internal structure of the earth
(ii) Describe the distinguishing characteristics of any one of the layers shown in your diagram

(b) Outline the importance of either the hydrosphere or the biosphere to man
answer:
(a)(i) Internal structure of the Earth

(ii) Characteristics of the crust:

(i) It is made up of upper part to form the continent

(ii) It is made up of granite and contains minerals like silicon and aluminum hence called SIAL

(iii) Its density is 2.7

(iv) It also contains the lower part to form the ocean floor

(vi) It is made up of basalt rocks and contains minerals like silicon, iron and magnesium hence called SIMA

(vi) It has a density of 3.0

(b) Importance of hydrosphere to man include:

(i) Hydrosphere provides water for domestic and industrial uses

(ii) It also provides means of transportation

(iii) It provides food, e.g fish

(iv) It can help to generate electricity (H.E.P)

question:
(a) Highlight the economic importance of oceans to man, giving specific examples

(b) Select any one warm current in the North Atlantic Ocean and describe the factors responsible for its movement
answer:
(a) Economic importance of oceans to man include:

(i) Oceans serve as a means of transportation and communication

(ii) They serve as sources of food, e.g fish, crayfish, etc.

(iii) Oceans, e.g continental shelf provide minerals like petroleum and natural gas

(iv) Oceans provide employment to many people e.g fishermen, sailors etc

(v) Extraction of both domestic and industrial salts

(b) One warm current in the North Atlantic Ocean is Floride current.

Factors responsible for its movement include:

(i) Planetary winds. These winds by their nature blow across oceans resulting in the movement of water

(ii) The rotation of the earth

(iii) Differences in temperature

(iv) The shape of the land masses

(v) Salinity of the water

question:
(a)(i) Name the three climatic belts recognised by the Greek system of classification
(ii) What is the basis of this classification?

(b) State one characteristic of each of the recognised belts

(c) What three advantages has the Koppen's classification over the Greek system?
answer:
(a)(i) The three climatic belts recognised by the Greek system of classification include:
(i) Torid belt
(ii) Temperate belt
(iii) Frigid belt

(iii) The basis of classification is temperature

(b) One characteristic of each of the belts:

(i) Torrid belt: It is found in the tropics with high temperatures throughout the year

(ii) Temperate belt: It has a seasonal contrast in temperature

(iii) The frigid belt has very low temperature throughout the year.

(c) Three advantages of Koppen's classification over the Greek system include:

(i)It is simple to understand

(ii) It is objective

(iii) It is commonly used in teaching at different levels of educational institutions.

question:
(a) Highlight the distinguishing characteristics of the natural vegetation associated with either the cool temperate (eastern margin type) or the tropical continental climate

(b) Explain the sectors that have aided the occurrence of the vegetation type in the area you have selected.
answer:
(a) Characteristics of natural vegetation associated with the tropical continental climate:

(i) The dominant vegetation cover is grass

(ii) Presence of tall grasses that are fibrous when old

(iii) The trees are deciduous, i.e they sheath, leaves during the dry season to reduce transpiration

(iv) Presence of short scattered trees

(b) Favourable factors for this type of vegetation include:

(i) Low rainfall of about 600-1500cm per annum

(ii) Extremes of temperature which ranges from 21-32°C

(iii) It has an annual temperature range of 11°C

(v) It has high monthly temperature of about 27°C

(v) The vegetation has a single maximum of rainfall

question:
(a) Describe five causes of flooding

(b) In what four ways can flooding be controlled?
answer:
(a) Five causes of flooding include:

(i) Excessive rainfall

(ii) Poor drainage system or lack of culverts

(iii) Erection of buildings on watershed

(iv) Inadequate urban planning

(v) Erection of week dams and embankments

(b) Four ways of controlling floods include:

(i) Channelization of flood from city centres

(ii) Public enlightenment on effects of flooding

(ii;) Construction of wider culverts or good drainage system

(iv) Installation of strong dams to act as flood reservoirs

question:
(a) Describe the significance of minerals as an environmental resource

(b) Highlight three major problems resulting from the exploitation of mineral resources
answer:
(a) Significance of minerals as environmental resources include:

(i) It provides fuel, e.g petroleum, coal and natural gas

(ii) It provides foreign exchange

(iii) Provision of employment, i.e mining

(iv) Provision of basic amenities where mining is carried out

(v) Provision of raw materials for industries, e.g limestone for cement industries

(vi) Some are valuable minerals used in making necklace, wrist watches e.g gold.

(b) Three major problems resulting from the exploitation of mineral resources include:

(i) Environmental pollutions

(ii) Depletion off natural vegetation

(iii) Mining activities do lead to soil erosion

question:
(a) Explain four ways in which a fall in birth rate can be beneficial to a country

(b) What four problems can arise from a fall in the birth rate of a country?

(c) In what four ways can the birth rate of such a country be increased?
answer:
(a) Four benefits of a fall in birth rate include:

(i) High per capita income

(ii) High standard of living

(iii) Adequacy of available social amenities and services for the people

(iv) Abundant food supply for the few people

(b) Four problems resulting from a fall in the birth rate of a country include:

(i) Inadequate skilled and unskilled labour

(ii) Low rate of exploitation of natural resources

(iii) Low rate of economic development

(iv) High dependency ratio, i.e. more of aged people than young ones

(c) Four ways of increasing the birth rate include:

(i) Encouragement of early marriages

(ii) Legislation in favour of abortion

(iii) Provision of benefits for single parents

(iv) Government incentives such as free medical care.

question:
(a) Explain any five functions which urban centres perform for rural areas

(b) What four problems may limit the performance of the functions identified in (a) above
answer:
(a) Five functions urban centres perform for rural areas include:

(i) Processing of raw materials from rural areas

(ii) Market for products from rural areas

(iii) Administrative centres for rural areas

(iv) Provision of employment for rural migrants

(v) Provision of social services e.g higher education

(b) Four problems that may limit the performance of the above functions include:

(i) Inadequate communication network between urban and rural areas

(ii) Inadequate jobs in the urban centres

(iii) Inadequate capital for processing

(iv) Political discrimination

question:
(a) In what fours ways is water transportation important in international trade?

(b) Highlight four limitations of water transpiration

(c) How can these limitations be overcome?
answer:
(a) Four ways in which water transportation is important to international trade

(i) It covers long distance

(ii) It is very cheap

(iii) It can carry bulky goods

(iv) It aids transportation of passengers

(b) Four limitations include:

(i) Water transportation is too slow for passengers and perishable goods

(ii) Presence of waterfalls and cataracts

(iii) Ports may be silted up or frozen

(iv) Problems of sea weeds or water hyacinth

(c) The above limitations can be overcome by

(i) Continuos dredging

(ii) Improved technology

(iii) Continuous clearing of sea weeds

(iv) Construction of canals to bypass falls

question:
(a) Explain any five factors that should be considered in the location of a cement factory

(b) Describe any three problems facing cement factories in Tropical Africa
answer:
(a) Five factors for the location of cement factory include:

(i) Presence of raw materials e.g limestone

(ii) Presence of large market

(iii) Source of power e.g H.E.P

(iv) Availability of capital

(v) Adequate transportation networks

(b) Three problems facing cement factories are:

(i) Inadequate capital to procure machinery

(ii) Inadequate spare parts to service machines

(iii) Inadequate transportation network.

question:
(a) Account for the inter-dependence in trade between Nigeria and Britain

(b) What four factors may limit this trade?

(c) State three ways by which the trade between the two countries can be improved
answer:
(a) Inter-dependence in trade between Nigeria and Britain include:

(i) Differences in physical setting, e.g climate

(ii) Differences in products - agricultural and manufactured goods

(iii) The need to earn foreign exchange

(iv) Colonial linkage

(b) Four factors limiting the trade include:

(i) Inadequate production of goods

(ii) Low demand for products

(iii) Political instability

(iv) High tariffs on goods

(c) Three ways of improving the trade include:

(i) Increased production by both countries

(ii) Membership of the same international economic organisation

(iii) Increased international co-operation between both countries

question:
(a) On an outline map of Nigeria, locate and name
(i) an inland drainage basin
(ii) a delta
(iii) a man-made lake
(iv) a confluence town

(b) In what four ways can physical factors limit the use of rivers for transportation in Nigeria?

question:

(i) the savanna belts and one important town in each of the belts

(b) Highlight three vegetation characteristics of any one of the savanna belts shown on your map

(c) Describe the relationship between vegetation and rainfall in the savanna belts. Give reasons for any three of the following in Nigeria
answer:
(b) Characteristics of Guinea Savanna; 

(i) Presence of tall trees

(ii) Presence of tall grasses

question:
(a) Market gardening is predominantly practised around major urban areas

(b) Lumbering is practised mainly in the high forest belt

(c) Rice is cultivated in large quantity in the Middle Belt

(d) Cattle rearing is important in the Sudan Savanna Belt.
answer:
(a) Reasons for market gardening in urban areas include:

(i) Produce are in high demand - such as vegetable, fruits, etc.

(ii) The need to be close to a large market

(iii) It does not need a large expanse of land

(iv) Presence of good network of routes

(b) Lumbering in the high forest belts:

(i) Presence of suitable climatic conditions-high rainfall throughout the year

(ii) Presence of forest trees

(iii) Presence of varieties of species

(iv) Presence of hardwood for construction purposes

(c) Rice in middle belt; 

(i) Presence of large expanse of land due to low population

(ii) Presence of adequate climatic conditions, e.g rainfall of over 125cm

(iii) Abundance of swampy areas along river valley

(iv) Absence of export crops.

question:
Describe how each of the following factors affects the climate of Africa

(a) Latitude (b) Ocean currents (c) Distance from the sea
answer:
(a) Effects of latitude on climate of Africa

(i) Insolation if more direct at the equator and included at the tropics

(ii) Rainfall amount is higher at the low latitudes than at the high latitude

(iii) There is rainfall all the year round at the low latitudes and seasonal in high latitudes

(b) Effects of ocean currents

(i) It determines the amount of rainfall
(ii) It affects rain formation
(iii) It leads to coastal fogs
(iv) It modifies temperature 

(c) Distance from the sea

(i) Extremes of temperature in the interior
(ii) It is higher in the interior
(iii) Higher humidity along the coast
(iv) It also leads to thicker cloud cover along the coast

question:

(iv) Large market for produce

(b) Four importance of plantation agriculture include; 

(i) Provision of employment

(ii) It supplies cash crops

(iii) It provide: raw materials for industries

(iv) It provides foreign exchange

(c) Four problems of plantation agriculture include:

(i) Foreign ownership of farms

(ii) Infestation of pests and diseases

(iii) Fluctuation in prices of produce
